caption.body: In 1926, Maude Campbell became the first female passenger to fly aboard a Western Air Express flight and is reported to be the first female passenger to fly on a scheduled commercial flight in the United States. As a young secretary in 1926, she flew from Salt Lake City to Los Angeles via Las Vegas on Western Air Express. Borrowing a leather flying suit and goggles from a pilot, she sat in-between sacks of mail in the open-cockpit of a wood and fabric Douglas M-2. The 650-mile trip took 6 hours.  Image: Western Air Express, Maude Campbell, Harris “Pop” Hanshue, 1926. Gift of Barbara A. Dawson. 2000.073.007
caption.excerpt: In 1926, Maude Campbell became the first female passenger to fly aboard a Western Air Express flight and is reported to be the first female passenger to fly on a scheduled commercial flight in the United States.
